application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: A theory of resource-bounded dimension is developed using gales, which are natural generalizations of martingales. When the resource bound (a parameter of the theory) is unrestricted, the resulting dimension is precisely the classical Hausdor dimension (sometimes called \fractal dimension"). Other choices of the parameter yield internal dimension theories in E, E 2 , ESPACE, and other complexity classes, and in the class of all decidable problems. In general, if C is such a class, then every set X of languages has a dimension in C, which is a real number dim(X j C) 2 [0; 1]. Along with the elements of this theory, two preliminary applications are presented:
1. For every real number 0 1 2 , the set FREQ(
), consisting of all languages that asymptotically contain at most of all strings, has dimension H( ) | the binary entropy of | in E and in E 2 .
2. For every real number 0 1, the set SIZE( 2 n n ), consisting of all languages decidable by Boolean circuits of at most 2 n n gates, has dimension in ESPACE.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Since the development of resource-bounded measure in 1991 [9], the investigation of the internal, measure-theoretic structure of complexity classes has produced a rapidly growing body of new insights and results. As indicated by the survey papers [1,3,10,12], this line of inquiry has shed light on a wide variety of topics in computational complexity. The ongoing fruitfulness of this research is not surprising because resource-bounded measure is a complexity-theoretic generalization of classical Lebesgue measure, which was one of the most powerful quantitative tools of twentiethcentury mathematics.

In spite of this power, there are certain inherent limitations to the amount of quantitative information that resource-bounded measure can provide in computational complexity. One of these limitation arises from the resource-bounded Kolmogorov zero-one law, which was proven by Lutz [11] and has recently been strengthened by Dai [4]. For any class C in which resourcebounded measure is de ned, and for any set X of languages that is | like most sets of interest in computational complexity | closed under nite variations, the zero-one law says that the measure of X in C must be 0 or 1 or unde ned. A second limitation arises from the simple fact that even a measure 0 subset of a complexity class may have internal structure that we would like to elucidate quantitatively. Of course both these limitations were already present in classical Lesbesgue measure theory.

In 1919, Hausdor [7] augmented classical Lesbesgue measure theory with a theory of dimension. This theory assigns to every subset X of a given metric space a real number dim H (X), which is now called the Hausdor dimension of X. In this paper, we are interested in the case where the metric space is the Cantor space C, consisting of all decision problems (i.e., all languages A f0; 1g ). In this case the Hausdor dimension of a set X C (which is de ned precisely in section 3) is a real number dim H (X) 2 [0; 1]. The Hausdor dimension is monotone, with dim H (;) = 0 and dim H (C) = 1. Moreover, if dim H (X) < dim H (C), then X is a measure 0 subset of C. Hausdor dimension thus overcomes both of the limitations mentioned in the preceding paragraph.

In this paper we develop resource-bounded dimension, which is a complexity-theoretic generalization of classical Hausdor dimension. We carry out this generalization in two steps. We rst prove a new characterization of classical Hausdor dimension in terms of gales, which are a natural generalization of the martingales that are the basis of resource-bounded measure. (Our characterization can be regarded as an analog of Ville's martingale characterization of the Lesbesgue measure 0 sets [19].) We then generalize classical dimension by introducing a resource bound (a parameter of the theory) and requiring the gales to be -computable. We show that this induces a well-behaved notion of dimension in the corresponding class R( ), which is de ned exactly as in resource-bounded measure. We write dim(X j R( )) for the dimension of the set X in the class R( ). If is unrestricted, then R( ) = C and dim(X j R( )) = dim(X j C) is precisely dim H (X). However, other choices of allow R( ) to be interesting complexity classes, in which case dim(X j R( )) is a quantitative measure of the dimension of X \ R( ) as a subset of R( ).

After presenting the elements of resource-bounded dimension, we present two preliminary applications of the theory. First, for each real number 2 [0; 1], let FREQ( ) be the set of all languages that asymptotically contain at most of all strings. (This set is de ned precisely in section 5.) We prove that, for every real number 2 [0; 1 2 ], dim(FREQ(
div.formula: j E) = H( ) and dim(FREQ( ) j E 2 ) = H( ) ;
div.p: where E = DTIME(2 linear ), E 2 = DTIME(2 poly ), and H is the binary entropy function of Shannon information theory.

Our second application concerns Boolean circuit-size complexity in the complexity class ESPACE = DSPACE(2 linear ). For each real number 2 [0; 1], let SIZE( 2 n n ) be the set of all languages that can be decided by Boolean circuits consisting of at most 2 n n gates. We prove that for all
div.formula: 2 [0; 1], dim(SIZE( 2 n n ) j ESPACE) = :
div.p: These applications are interesting because they show that resource-bounded dimension interacts informatively with information theory and Boolean circuit-size complexity. However, they are clearly only the beginning. Classical Hausdor dimension is a sophisticated mathematical theory that has emerged as one of the most important tools for the investigation of fractal sets. (See, for example [6] for a good introduction and overview.) Many sets of interest in computational complexity seem to have \fractal-like" structures. Resource-bounded dimension will be a useful tool for the study of such sets.

div.head: Preliminaries
div.p: A decision problem (a.k.a. language) is a set A f0; 1g . We identify each language with its characteristic sequence [[s

, where s 0 ; s 1 ; s 2 ; : : : is the standard enumer-ation of f0; 1g and [[ ]] = if then 1 else 0. We write A[i::j] for the string consisting of the i-th through j-th bits of (the characteristic sequence of) A. The Cantor space C is the set of all decision problems. If w 2 f0; 1g and x 2 f0; 1g [ C, then w v x means that w is a pre x of x, and w <
x means that w is a proper pre x of x. The cylinder generated by a string w 2 f0; 1g is

div.p: A pre x set is a language A such that no element of A is a pre x of any other element of A.
If A is a language and n 2 N, then we write A =n = A \ f0; 1g n and A n = A \ f0; 1g n . All logarithms in this paper are base 2.

Within the class DEC of all decidable languages, we are interested in the exponential com-
div.formula: plexity classes E i = DTIME(2 G i 1 ) and E i SPACE = DSPACE(2 G i 1 ) for i 1. The much- studied classes E = E 1 = DTIME(2 linear ), E 2 = DTIME(2 polynomial

A constructor is a function : f0; 1g ! f0; 1g that satis es x < 6 = (x) for all x. The result of a constructor (i.e., the language constructed by ) is the unique language R( ) such that n ( ) v R( ) for all n 2 N. Intuitively, constructs R( ) by starting with and then iteratively generating successively longer pre xes of R( ). We write R( ) for the set of languages R( ) such that is a constructor in . The following facts are the reason for our interest in the above-de ned classes of functions.
div.formula: R(all) = C. R(comp) = DEC. For i 1, R(p i )=E i . For i 1, R(p i space) = E i SPACE. If D is a discrete domain, then a function f : D ! [0; 1) is -computable if there is a function f : N D ! Q \ [0; 1) such that j f (r; x) f (x)j

div.head: Gales and Hausdor Dimension
div.p: In this section we introduce gales and supergales, which are a generalization of martingales and supermartingales, and use these to give a new characterization of classical Hausdor dimension.

div.p: We now review the classical de nition of Hausdor dimension. Since we are primarily interested in the computational complexities of decision problems, we focus on Hausdor dimension in the Cantor space C.
For each k 2 N, we let A k be the collection of all pre x sets A such that A <k = ;. For each X C, we then let

div.p: Digression. Readers familiar with Hausdor dimension may prefer to regard it as arising from a measure or, more commonly, a metric on the underlying space. If we regard Hausdor dimension as arising from a measure on C, then the term 2 sjwj in the above sum in interpreted as (C w ) s , where (C w ) = 2 jwj is the Lebesgue measure of the cylinder C w . If we instead regard Hausdor dimension as arising from a metric on C, then the metric is
div.formula: d(A; B) = 2 minfn2NjA[n]6 =B[n]g
div.p: (where min ; = 1 so d(A; A) = 0), and the term 2 sjwj is interpreted as diam(C w ) s , where
div.formula: diam(X) = sup A;B2X d(A; B)
div.p: is the diameter of a set X C. Such interpretations may provide context, but our technical development does not use them.
De nition. For s 2 [0; 1) and X C, the s-dimensional Hausdor outer measure of X is
div.formula: H s (X) = lim k!1 H s k (X) :
div.p: Since H s k (X) is nondecreasing in k, this limit H s (X) exists, though it may be in nite. In fact, it is well-known that for every set X C, there is a real number s 2 [0; 1] with the following two properties.
(i) For all 0 s < s , H s (X) = 1.
(ii) For all s > s , H s (X) = 0.
As the following de nition states, this number s is the Hausdor dimension of X.

div.head: Dimension in Complexity Classes
div.p: Motivated by the gale characterization of classical Hausdor dimension, we now use resourcebounded gales to develop dimension in complexity classes. As with resource-bounded measure [9], our development contains a parameter | the resource bound | which may be any one of the classes all, comp, p, pspace, p 2 , p 2 space, etc., de ned in section 2.
Notation. For X C, let G (X) be the set of all s 2 [0; 1) such that there is a -computable s-gale d for which
div.formula: X S 1 [d]. De nition. Let X C. 1. The -dimension of X is dim (X) = inf G (X). 2. The dimension of X in R( ) is dim(X j R( )) = dim (X \ R( )).
div.p: Note that dim (X) and dim(X j R( )) are de ned for every set X C. We call dim comp (X) and dim p (X) the computable dimension of X and the feasible dimension of X, respectively.
The following observations are elementary but useful.

The fth observation above shows that resource-bounded dimension o ers a quantitative classi cation of sets that have resource-bounded measure 0. However, it should be emphasized that this classi cation is in terms of dimension, which is very di erent from measure. For example, Lemma 4.8 and its corollaries exhibit properties of dimension that contrast sharply with those of measure.

To proceed further, we need a little bit of technical machinery concerning the computability of gales and supergales. Proof: Assume the hypothesis. We now note that nite sets of languages have resource-bounded dimension 0, provided that the languages themselves do not exceed the resource bound. Lemma 4.12. If = all, then Lemma 4.13 is the well-known fact that every countable set has Hausdor dimension 0. For smaller resource bounds , Lemma 4.13 has consequences of the following sort. Analogous results hold in ESPACE, REC, etc. As noted above, every countable class of languages has Hausdor dimension 0. In contrast, we now show that, even for countable resource bounds , the -dimension of R( ) is 1. This result, which is analogous to the Measure Conservation Theorem of [9], endows the classes R( ) with internal dimensional structure. (In fact, by Observation 4.1, this result follows from the Measure Conservation Theorem, but we prove it directly here.)

We conclude this section by mentioning some relevant earlier work relating martingales and supermartingales to computable dimension. Schnorr [14,15] de ned a martingale d to have exponential order on a sequence (equivalently, language) S if lim sup

and proved that no computable martingale can have exponential order on a Church-stochastic sequence. Terwijn [18] has noted that (4.1) is equivalent to the existence of an s < 1 for which the s-gale d (s) (w) = 2 (s 1)jwj d(w) succeeds on S. Thus Schnorr's result says that dim comp (fSg) = 1 for every Church-stochastic sequence S.

Ryabko [13] and Staiger [17] de ned the exponent of increase d (S) of a martingale d on a sequence S to be the left-hand side of (4.1). (We are using Staiger's notation here.) Both papers paid particular attention to the quantity (S) = supf d (S)jd is a computable martingaleg: (4.2) By Terwijn's above-mentioned observation, 1 (S) is precisely dim comp (fSg). The reader is referred to these papers for interesting results relating (S) { and hence computable dimension { to Kolmogorov complexity and Hausdor dimension.

div.head: Dimension and Frequency in Exponential Time
div.p: In this section we show that for each 0 s 1 there is a natural set X that has dimension s in each of the exponential time complexity classes E and E 2 . This set X consists of those languages that asymptotically contain at most of all strings, where 0 That is, freq A (n) is the fraction of the rst n strings in f0; 1g that are elements of A. For 2 [0; 1], de ne the sets FREQ( ) = fA 2 C j lim

div.p: The set FREQ( ) is the set X promised in the preceding paragraph. Our results use the binary entropy function
(The values H(0) and H(1) are both 0, so that H is continuous on [0, 1].) Our proofs use the \weighted entropy" function h : (0; 1) (0; 1) ! R h(x; y) = x log 1 y + (1 x) log 1 1 y :
For xed x, h(x; y) takes its minimum value H(x) at y = x and strictly increases as y moves away from x.

From these two lemmas we get the main result of this section.
Theorem 5.3.
1. For all -computable 2 [0; 1], dim(FREQ( ) j R( )) = H( ).

1. This follows immediately from Lemma 5.1, Lemma 5.2, and Observation 4.1. Since this holds for all rational 0 and H is continuous, it follows that dim(FREQ( ) j R( )) H( ) :
The case = all of Theorem 5.3 says simply that the classical Hausdor dimensions of FREQ( ) and FREQ(

) are both H( ). This was proven in 1949 by Eggleston [5,2]. The proof here yields a new proof, using gales, of this classical result. However, it is complexity-theoretic results of the following kind that are of interest in this paper.
Corollary 5.4.
1. For all p-computable reals 2 [0; 1], dim(FREQ( ) j E) = dim(FREQ( ) j E 2 ) = H( ) :
2. For all 2 [0; 1 2 ], dim(FREQ( ) j E) = dim(FREQ( ) j E 2 ) = H( ) :
Since H(0) = 0, H( 1 2 ) = 1, and H is continuous, part 2 of the corollary implies that for every s 2 [0; 1] there exists 2 [0; 1 2 ] such that dim(FREQ( ) j E) = dim(FREQ( ) j E 2 ) = s :

div.head: Dimension and Circuit Size in Exponential Space
div.p: We now examine the dimensions of Boolean circuit-size complexity classes in the complexity class ESPACE.

Our Boolean circuit model and terminology are standard. Details may be found in [9], but our result is not sensitive to minor details of the model. The circuit-size complexity of a language A f0; 1g is the function CS A : N ! N, where CS A (n) is the number of gates in the smallest n-input Boolean circuit that decides A \ f0; 1g n . For each function f : N ! N, we de ne the circuit-size complexity class SIZE(f ) = fA 2 C j (8 1 n)CS A (n) f (n)g :

div.p: Acknowledgment. I am very grateful to Elvira Mayordomo and John Hitchcock for useful discussions.
This research was supported in part by National Science Foundation Grants 9610461 and 9988483.

Shannon [16] showed (essentially) that SIZE( 2 n n ) has measure 0 in C for all < 1, and Lutz [9] showed that SIZE ( 2 n n ) also has measure 0 in ESPACE for all < 1. We now use resource-bounded dimension to give a quantitative re nement of these results.

Assume that all n-input Boolean circuits are enumerated in a canonical order in which all circuits of size (number of gates) t precede all those of size t + 1 for all t 2 Z + . Call a circuit in this enumeration novel if there is not previous circuit in the enumeration that decides the same subset of f0; 1g n . For each n 2 N and t 2 Z + , let N (n; t) be the number of novel n-input Boolean circuits with at most t gates. The following speci c bound on N (n; t) was proven in [9], but as noted there, the idea is essentially due to Shannon [16] (ii) Assume that d(w) has been de ned, where jwj = 2 n 1 for some n 2 N. For each u with 0 < juj 2 n , de ne d(wu) = 2 sjuj (u)d(w), where

and N (n; t; u) is the number of novel n-input Boolean circuits with at most t gates that decide the sets B f0; 1g n whose rst juj decisions are the bits of u. It is easy to check that d is an exactly pspace-computable s-gale. The de nition of d implies that if jwj = 2 n 1 and u is the characteristic string of a set B f0; 1g n that can be decided by a circuit with at most
n gates, then for su ciently large n,

then for all su ciently large n there are at least 2 2 n di erent sets B f0; 1g n that are decided by Boolean circuits of fewer than 2 n n gates. Proof: Let m = n + log . Then there are 2 2 m = 2 2 n di erent sets C f0; 1g m . If we let " = 2 , so that = (1 2"), then for all su ciently large n, Lupanov [8] has shown that each of these sets is decided by a circuit of at most 2 m m (1 + ") gates. Now for su ciently large n,
Thus, for each C f0; 1g m , if we let B C = fw0 n m j w 2 Cg, then B C is decided by a Boolean circuit of fewer than 2 n n gates. 2
Recall that in section 2 we de ned constructors and showed that R(pspace) = ESPACE.
Lemma 6.4. For every real 2

Proof: This is clear if = 0, so assume that 2 (0; 1]. Let 0 < s < with 2 s rational, and let d be an arbitrary s-gale. De ne a constructor : f0; 1g ! f0; 1g as follows. If jwj is not of the form 2 n 1, then (w) = w0. If jwj is of the form 2 n 1 (i.e., w is the characteristic string of a subset of f0; 1g <n ), then (w) = wu, where u is the rst string in f0; 1g 2 n that minimizes max vvu d(wv), subject to the constraint that u is the characteristic string of a set B f0; 1g n that is decided by a Boolean circuit with fewer than Proof: This follows immediately from Lemma 6.2, Lemma 6.4, and Observation 4.1. 2

We note that for any < 1, Lutz [9] has shown that the class SIZE( 2 n n (1 + log n n )) has measure 0 in ESPACE and in C. By the above results, this class is thus a natural example of a set that, in both ESPACE and C, has dimension 1 but measure 0.
